title.narrative: Capacity Development of Transparency International Ukraine

description.narrative: Civil society backed and supported mainly by international donors, has played an important role throughout the events in the post-Maidan period and significantly contributed to the number of reforms. During the Ukrainian Revolution of Dignity in 2014, TIU was seen by foreign and national stakeholders as an important and objective source of information of what was happening. Its stakeholders still see this as an important reason for supporting and cooperating with TIU. Since then, TIU has worked to develop and improve anti-corruption infrastructures (with the creation of anti-corruption bodies), with the reform and monitoring of public procurement in Ukraine (developing and then transferring the digital tools of ProZorro, ProZorro.sale and eHealth to the state). In this regard, Transparency International Ukraine (TI Ukraine), although functioning for some 20 years now, but enquiring its current name in 2014, is especially seen to be still well positioned to respond to the challenges of post-Maidan, societal and political developments. In 2019, TI Ukraine has engaged in a dialogue with the Embassy of Sweden regarding a potential support, while submitting a specific proposal soliciting funding for the i) institutional development as well as ii) the Prozorro.sale instrument enhancement. The Project's general objective is to strengthen the potential of Transparency International Ukraine as an organization and enhance efficiency in its strategy implementation as well as increase capacity of Prozorro.Sale and develop a civic monitoring infrastructure around it. As part of Sweden’s risk management, it was decided to carry out a Systems-Based Audit (SBA) in order to obtain recommendations as a basis for a decision to either provide project-based support, or to provide other funding (core support funding of TI Ukraine) in pursuing the overarching goal of lowering the level of corruption in Ukraine. According to the Strategy of Transparency International Ukraine for 2019-2021, there are 3 strategic mainstreams to reduce corruption levels: Prevention: Mitigate corruption risks at the national and the local level by increasing transparency and accountability in authorities’ work. Engagement: Engage the maximum number of participants and create conditions enabling them to unite into effective networks by providing them with regular support. Punishment: Ensure an effective system of punishment for corruption-related violations Within this intervention, TI Ukraine will implement its strategy in three priorities in the areas of Business Integrity; Anti-Corruption Policy Development and Analysis; Raising Awareness and Change of Perception Among Citizens, Betterment of the Perception of Ukraine Among Foreign Stakeholders. Inherting a post-soviet economic system of governance Ukraine still to date has substantial assets in public ownership at all adminstrative levels. While a process of privatisation has to date had mixed results, and mispricing and misuse of state property has historically been a huge issue. The lack of transparency has typically benefitted a small group of allied rent-seekers in the private and public sphere. Within the perimeters of the contribution in question, the team with work with the State-Owned Enterprise Prozorro.Sale to make the advancement of IT solutions and establish monitoring and oversight of state assets sale and lease. This will reduce corruption and enable effective use of state assets by transparent transactions between the state and the private sector (and in particular SMEs). TI Ukraine’s Legal Department shall contribute to the implementation of organization’s strategic priorities supporting the bodies of Anti-Corruption infrastructure (NABU, SAPO, NACP, HACC, ARMA) to ensure an effective system of investigation, prosecution and justice for corruption-related offenses and recovery of assets obtained in result of crime. In particular, our legal experts closely cooperate with the National Agency for Corruption Prevention, conduct assessment of the anti-corruption infrastructure bodies of Ukraine to enhance their work, develop the capacity and improve the legislation on the Asset Recovery and Management Agency, monitor work of the High Anti-Corruption Court. In addition, TI Ukraine aims at implementing a Business Integrity Program (BIP) to reduce corruption levels through improved transparency, accountability and integrity in business practices. TI Ukraine will undertake actions to increase the number of businesses in public and private sector operating without corruption. This will be achieved as a result of better business regulations on a country level, well-developed internal anti-corruption and ethics procedures and practices, as well as through establishment of a new platform for experience exchange and support. Within the course of the project, TI Ukraine will conduct research on transparency in public reporting (TRAC), carry out a Business Integrity Country Agenda (BICA) assessment report, establish cooperation with at least three selected state-owned enterprises, as well as launch a Business Integrity Forum (BIF).

Transparency International Ukraine (TI Ukraine), with over 20 years’ track record of work to enhance public integrity, boost transparency of public finances usage and fight against corruption is well positioned to respond to the challenges of post-Maidan, societal and political developments.
To tis end, TIU has worked to develop and improve anti-corruption infrastructures (with the creation of anti-corruption bodies), with the reform and monitoring of public procurement in Ukraine (developing and then transferring the digital procurement tools of ProZorro, ProZorro.sale and eHealth to the state).
In 2019, TI Ukraine has engaged in a dialogue with the Embassy of Sweden regarding a potential support, while submitting a specific proposal soliciting funding for further institutional development of the TI Ukraine CSO.
Within this intervention, TI Ukraine will enhance its institutional capacities, while implementing its strategy in three priorities: 1) in the area of Business Integrity; 2) Anti-Corruption Policy development and analysis; and 3) raising awareness and change of perception among citizens, betterment of Ukraine’s image among foreign stakeholders, while enhancing its organizational capacities.
The proposal put forward by TI is relevant for the current "Results strategy for Sweden´s reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2020", and in particular results areas 1 and 2.

Transparency International Ukraine (TIU) har arbetat i över 20 år för att öka transparensen av offentliga finanser och för att bekämpa korruption. Organisationen är väl lämpad att möta de utmaningarna som Ukraina står inför efter Värdighetsrevolutionen, samt de politiska och samhälleliga utvecklingarna som sker i landet.
TIU har arbetat för att utveckla och förbättra infrastrukturen för korruptionsbekämpning (genom inrättandet av organ för korruptionsbekämpning). De har även arbetat med reformering och övervakning av processer för offentlig upphandling i Ukraina (de har utvecklat och överfört de digitala upphandlingsverktygen ProZorro, ProZorro.sale och eHealth till den ukrainska staten).
Under 2019 har TIU inlett en dialog med Sveriges ambassad om eventuellt stöd, samtidigt som de lämnat in ett specifikt förslag som begär finansiering för vidare institutionell utveckling av TIU.
Inom denna komponent kommer TIU att stärka sin institutionella kapacitet och samtidigt genomföra sin strategi inom tre områden: 1) företagsrättrådighet; 2) utvecklande och analys av antikorruptionspolicy; och 3) öka medvetenheten och förändra uppfattningen bland medborgarna, förbättra bilden av Ukraina bland utländska motparter. Allt detta samtidigt som TIU:s organisatoriska kapacitet förbättras.
Förslaget från TIU är relevant för den nuvarande "Resultatstrategin för Sveriges reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014-2020", och då särskilt resultatområdena 1 och 2.
